title: Fun Floating Furniture by Bote
description: Summer's almost here. Bote, a company that makes "water lifestyle products," has a line of floating furniture for when you want to hang out in the drink. Each feature their "Magnepod" system, whereby you can magnetically attach the company's drinkware to the furniture. And because they're all inflatable, they break down for storage, making them easy to toss into car trunks and backpacks. Their Sling Chair seats one: Their Hangout Couch can seat three, and can be attached to create a floating conversation dock: And their circular Hammock series can seat a variable number. They come in 7', 10' and 15' diameters: Sure you can use these in a pool, but these look more at home in a proper body of water. Meaning yeah, you'll need that boat. The real move is to simply know someone who owns one. I hear the best two days of owning a boat, are the day you buy it, and the day you sell it.
author: Rain Noe

title: Freitag Creates a Completely Monomaterial and Recyclable Bag Line
description: Take a look at your favorite bag. How many different materials is it made out of? The backpack and musette bag in Freitag's Mono[PA6] series contain 17 different components: Buckles, straps, zippers, sewing thread, fabric, lanyards, etc. Amazingly, all 17 components are made of the exact same material: PA6, a variant of nylon. This is significant because it means the entire bag can be recycled, without having to dismantle the bag piece by piece. Freitag will take the bags back when you're done with them and recycle them in their entirety. And being Freitag products, the bags are both tough and water-repellent.The PA6 material isn't off-the-shelf nylon; engineering was required. "The search for a single-material fabric that could repel water proved fruitless," the company writes. "Most fabrics like that use coatings or membranes made of other materials. And because we were looking for a mono-material, that was out of the question. So, with a partner, we developed a brand-new fabric that's both water-repellent and a mono-material."The backpack runs $380 and the musette $101.
author: Rain Noe

title: When Life Breaks You Open: The Real Story Behind My Newest Mini Course
description: Loss sucks. In 2020, I found out that my father had passed away the year before in 2019 - his cancer came back, and he didn’t have a second battle left in him. I hadn’t known because my mother, who had Lewy Body Dementia, had forgotten to tell me, or rather, she said she thought she did tell me.

title: How to Stain a Fiberglass Door {To Look Like Wood!}
description: How to stain a fiberglass entry door in a rich wood color.  One of the most common questions I get is about the stain we used on our wood front door. Turns out our door isn't wood, but it is stained to look like it.  Did you know you can stain a fiberglass door and it will look just like wood? I didn't realize this until we built our current house. I had no idea you could use stain on anything but wood, and I've been at this DIY thing for a long time! We have a Therma Tru door set with sidelites (see specifics of our indoor and outdoor home finishes here) and picked the stain color called English Walnut.  Our front door doesn't get much of the elements because it's protected on our front porch. But even without the wind and rain hitting it directly, the dark stain was still super faded nearly eight years later.  I'm prepping for our son's high school graduation party, and this DIY project was on my list! The process wasn't nearly as difficult as I thought it would be. There are only a few simple steps in this application, they just take some time. The before photos of the door finish didn't look as horrible as in real life, but it was faded, worn out and chipping in some spots: This post may contain affiliate links for your convenience. I may earn a small commission when you make a purchase through links.  See my policies and disclosure page for more information.   Our builder didn't do a great job the first time this door was stained, so we had a lot of areas (particularly in more detailed spots) that were chipping away completely:  The builder left some of the leftover product, so I was able to look it up online and order more stain.  I went with the dark, rich English Walnut again in this same-day stain: Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. title: Five Tips to Save a TON on Flowers and Plants!
description: Five ways to save money on plants and flowers this planting season.Gardening is one of my favorite pastimes, but also one of the most expensive! Over the years I've come up with quite a few ways to save on both annual and perennial plants this time of year. Sometimes I will still splurge on a plant or tree, but for the most part these methods will save me a TON on flowers, bushes and trees for our gardens and yard. I've planted or replanted a TON of plants this spring (most were small, individual flowers) and have loved watching them thrive. I gathered my top five ways to save on plants this spring and summer! 1. Pick spreading plantsI love our window boxes, but they can be expensive to fill every spring. I learned years ago that using flowers that spread will make my money go a lot further. My favorite has always been the Wave Petunias because they multiply like crazy and cascade out of boxes or containers: These are the only annual flowers I plant each year because they spread and fill in so beautifully. Annuals only last one season, perennials will come back year after year.For your landscaping, look for ground cover or flowers that spread, like this awesome sedum plant I showed you years ago:Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC.
